<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 377, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 168, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 258]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[619, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 902, 258]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 303, 150, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 303, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 855, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a scientific calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- For \(\pi\) , use either your calculator value or 3.142.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 680]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 106, 782, 125]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 155, 675, 173]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 202, 683, 221]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 247, 680, 275]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 295, 683, 323]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 348, 655, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 367, 560, 402]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 446, 225, 463]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 437, 905, 480]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 483, 770, 526]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 217, 571]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 555, 667, 600]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 632, 217, 648]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 631, 570, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 740, 158, 756]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 739, 555, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 829, 240, 846]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 825, 576, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 75, 421, 93]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(\quad y = x^{2} + 2x - 3.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 146, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 918, 141]]<|/det|>
Use the method of completing the square to find the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 325, 146, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 754, 343]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the curve, stating the intercepts with the coordinate axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 325, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 365, 695, 653]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 365, 88]]<|/det|>
In this question, \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 87, 702, 106]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(2x^{2} + (3k - 2)x + k = 0\) has roots that are real and distinct.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 120, 395, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the set of possible values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 120, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 415, 94, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 443, 432]]<|/det|>
A sports club has the following members.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 437, 638, 454]]<|/det|>
\[5 \text{ runners, } 4 \text{ swimmers, } 3 \text{ gymnasts}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 146, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 469, 462, 486]]<|/det|>
These members stand in a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 500, 918, 532]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways that this can be done when all the runners stand together, all the swimmers stand together and all the gymnasts stand together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 514, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 148, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 670, 536, 687]]<|/det|>
Four of these members are selected for an event.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 701, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
Find the number of ways that this can be done when at least one runner, at least one swimmer and at least one gymnast must be selected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 715, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 549, 88]]<|/det|>
The coordinates of points \(A, B, C\) and \(D\) are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 96, 670, 113]]<|/det|>
\[A(-4,3)\quad B(6, - 9)\quad C(15,10)\quad D(14, - 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 425, 142]]<|/det|>
The line \(L\) has equation \(\quad y = 11x - 75.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 144, 620, 160]]<|/det|>
The perpendicular bisector of the line \(AB\) meets \(L\) at the point \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 175, 356, 190]]<|/det|>
Find the area of triangle \(CDE\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 175, 920, 190]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 94, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Given that \(y = x^{2}\tan \frac{x}{2}\) , use calculus to find the approximate change in \(y\) as \(x\) increases from \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) to \(\frac{\pi}{3} +h\) , where \(h\) is small.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Using an appropriate quadratic factorisation, find the first three terms in the binomial expansion of \(\left(9x^{2} + 12x + 4\right)^{5}\) , in ascending powers of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 108, 443, 125]]<|/det|>
You must simplify your coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 108, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 482, 146, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 472, 665, 508]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(\frac{6}{x^2} + \frac{x^4}{2}\right)^{12}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 481, 920, 500]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 74, 606, 93]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 2\mathrm{e}^{- x} + 3\) for \(x\in \mathbb{R}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 918, 142]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and hence, on the same axes, sketch the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 141, 262, 158]]<|/det|>
Show clearly

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 157, 785, 174]]<|/det|>
• the positions of any points where your graphs meet the coordinate axes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 173, 484, 190]]<|/det|>
• the positions of any asymptotes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 173, 918, 190]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 216, 695, 497]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 77, 621, 104]]<|/det|>
The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}(x) = 2 - \frac{3}{\mathrm{e}^{x} + 2}\) for \(x \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 110, 725, 131]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}\) exists, find an expression for \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\) and state its domain.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 110, 920, 129]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 94, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 146, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 77, 625, 98]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\left(2 - 3\cot x\right)\cos x = 0\) for \(0< x\leqslant \frac{\pi}{2}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(2\cos \mathrm{e}(2\theta +1) - 12\sin (2\theta +1) = 5,\) where \(\theta\) is in radians and \(-1\leqslant \theta \leqslant 2\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 70, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 70, 700, 90]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in centimetres and all angles are in radians.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 100, 834, 267]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 300, 625, 318]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(AOB\) of a circle, centre \(O\), radius 15.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 320, 262, 345]]<|/det|>
Angle \(AOB = \frac{6\pi}{5}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 345, 673, 363]]<|/det|>
The sector is made into a cone with points \(A\) and \(B\) touching, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 376, 146, 394]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 376, 475, 394]]<|/det|>
Find the curved surface area of the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 376, 920, 394]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 500, 440, 517]]<|/det|>
<pre>The top of the cone is a horizontal circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 532, 146, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 489, 551]]<|/det|>
Find the circumference of the circular top.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 146, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 670, 790, 688]]<|/det|>
Hence find the radius of the circular top and the perpendicular height of the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 670, 920, 688]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 390, 90]]<|/det|>
Water is poured into the cone.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 87, 861, 106]]<|/det|>
When the depth of the water in the cone is \(h\) , the radius of the circular top of the water is \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 180, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 120, 492, 136]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(r\) in terms of \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 304, 180, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 304, 767, 322]]<|/det|>
The water is poured into the cone at a constant rate of \(27 \text{cm}^3\) per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 918, 354]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which the depth of the water is rising when the depth of the water is 4. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 405, 88]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 751, 106]]<|/det|>
\(t\) seconds after passing a fixed point, \(O\) , the acceleration of \(P\) , \(a \mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\) , is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 121, 625, 160]]<|/det|>
\[a = t^{2} - 2\qquad \mathrm{for} 0\leqslant t\leqslant 4\] \[a = 19 - 5\mathrm{e}^{8 - 2t}\quad \mathrm{for} 4\leqslant t\leqslant 10.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 185, 744, 212]]<|/det|>
When \(t = 3\) , the velocity of \(P\) is \(- \frac{1}{3}\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) and its displacement from \(O\) is \(- \frac{1}{4}\mathrm{m}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 230, 146, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 230, 180, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 230, 463, 247]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity of \(P\) when \(t = 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 230, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 494, 180, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 494, 565, 511]]<|/det|>
Find the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) when \(t = 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 536, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) when \(t = 10\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[0, 106, 34, 999]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 863, 663, 880]]<|/det|>
Question 11 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 102, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 704, 90]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression has first term \(a\) and common ratio \(r\), where \(r > 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 88, 588, 104]]<|/det|>
The sum of the 2nd and 3rd terms of the progression is 168.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 103, 584, 120]]<|/det|>
The sum of the 4th and 5th terms of the progression is 94.5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 443, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the 6th term of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 585, 146, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 585, 490, 603]]<|/det|>
Find the sum to infinity of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 585, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[452, 945, 540, 958]]<|/det|>
0606/21/M/J/25
